info.name: MCP TIME QUEST @myapi
info.description:
```
mycli status          # ‚úÖ Shows player state, engine connection
mycli get-score       # ‚úÖ Returns current score with level
mycli set-score 150   # ‚úÖ Updates score, auto-levels player
mycli chat "hello"    # ‚úÖ Single message mode working
mycli chat -i         # ‚úÖ Interactive mode functional
mycli start-quest     # ‚úÖ Lists available quests
mycli quests          # ‚úÖ Shows quest status
mycli history         # ‚úÖ Conversation history
mycli config show     # ‚úÖ Configuration display

 ```

StartFragment

**Next step: Start the engine**

Open a **second terminal/command prompt** and start the engine:

``` bash
bashcd C:\Users\JefferyCaldwell\myMCP
npm run dev:engine

 ```

You should see something like:

``` bash
üöÄ myMCP Engine running on port 3000
üè• Health check: http://localhost:3000/health
üì° API base: http://localhost:3000/api
üéÆ Game states: 0 loaded
‚ö° Ready for service

 ```

Once the engine is running, go back to your first terminal and try the CLI command again:

``` bash
bashnpm run dev:cli -- status

 ```

This should now show your player status instead of the connection error.

**Alternatively**, you can test the engine health directly in a browser by visiting:  
`http://localhost:3000/health`

Let me know what happens when you start the engine!

EndFragment
